bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Frederick L. Rath, Jr., January 11, 1952

div1.p: Hench arranges to meet with Rath and General Grant, of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, to discuss the preservation of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Frederick L. Rath, Jr., January 11, 1952
div1.opener:
Desk-
January 11, 1952
Mr. Frederick L. Rath, Jr.
Director
National Trust for Historic Preservation
The Octagon House
Washington 6, D. C.
My dear Mr. Rath:
div1.p:
I appreciate very greatly your letter of December 21. Permit me to
send you a copy of a letter I have sent to Doctor Nogueira. It will
explain matters. I have also made contacts with three or four other
Cubans previously interested in this project, and it seems to me that
I might be able to get somewhere (however I have said this to myself
so often that I wonder why I keep saying it).

Nevertheless, permit me to thank you for your kind invitation to visit
you and General Grant. I am going to Cuba by way of Chicago and Miami
and will be gone from January 16 to about February 10. I am going to
Washington for a meeting of the Council of the National Institute for
Arthritis and Metabolic Diseases, February 23. Would it be agreeable
if I met you and General Grant, perhaps for lunch that day or possibly
on Friday, February 22. I could come to Washington a day early. I
think that would be preferable to Sunday, February 24, a day when all
of us probably need a day of rest.

I hope that I shall have some definite information to bring with me and
in any event, I will tell you the latest Cuban attitude on the matter
and I will bring with me a few photographs of the site and a little
summary of the project with some rough drawings of the building we
had in mind. Do you think General Grant would be interested in having
a copy of one or two of the articles I sent to you, particularly the
one that describes the significance of the little Cuban building and
how we found it. If so, he might like to have this before we meet and
I should be glad to send it to him now (if you will send my secretary
his address she will send it to him while I am away) or after my re-
turn from Cuba, before I come to Washington.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
